review.title: Automated Generation of Geometric Theorems from Images of Diagrams
review.abstract: We propose an approach to generate geometric theorems from electronic images of diagrams automatically. The approach makes use of techniques of Hough transform to recognize geometric objects and their labels and of numeric verification to mine basic geometric relations. Candidate propositions are generated from the retrieved information by using six strategies and geometric theorems are obtained from the candidates via algebraic computation. Experiments with a preliminary implementation illustrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed approach for generating nontrivial theorems from images of diagrams. This work demonstrates the feasibility of automated discovery of profound geometric knowledge from simple image data and has potential applications in geometric knowledge management and education.
histories: 31 pages. Submitted to Annals of Mathematics and Artificial Intelligence (special issue on Geometric Reasoning)
review.COMMENTS: 31 pages. Submitted to Annals of Mathematics and Artificial Intelligence (special issue on Geometric Reasoning)

metadata.title: Automated Generation of Geometric Theorems from Images of Diagrams

sections.text: We propose an approach to automatically generate geometric theorems from electronic mapping of diagrams using Hough transformation techniques to identify geometric objects and their labels, and numerical verification to obtain basic geometric relationships. Candidate proposals are generated from the retrieved information using six strategies, and geometric theorems are obtained by candidates using algebraic calculations. Experiments with a preliminary implementation illustrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed approach to generating non-trivial theorems from diagram images. This work demonstrates the feasibility of automated discovery of profound geometric knowledge from simple image data and has potential applications in geometric knowledge management and education.

sections.heading: 2 Information Retrieval from Images of Diagrams
sections.text: Geometric information consists of geometric objects (i.e. shapes used in geometric diagrams), their labels (i.e. the identifiers of the objects), and geometric relations (i.e. properties and characteristics of the objects).In the following, we will discuss how to retrieve information from diagram images and present it in a processable form for theory generation.

sections.heading: 2.3 Mining Basic Geometric Relations
sections.text: Some geometric relationships, such as those listed in Table 1, can be taken as basic geometric relationships. However, they cannot be used to derive most of the characteristics about the size and position of geometric objects and from them many other geometric relationships. < B > Point A is incidental to the line p and also to the line q, then the two relationships derive the new relationship that A is the intersection of the two lines p and q. Each basic geometric relationship in Table 1 corresponds to an algebraic equality in the coordinates of the points and radii involved in the circles. Generally, a geometric relationship can be judged to be true if and only if its corresponding equality applies. Take incident (C, line A, B) as an example and let the coordinates of A, B, and C be (x1, y1, y1), and (x2, y2), and (x3, y3), respectively.

sections.heading: 3 Automated Generation of Geometric Theorems
sections.text: It is noteworthy that geometric objects and their relationships derived from a single diagram image allow for explicit expression of certain non-trivial properties implicated in the diagram. Such properties generally apply to diagram families and can be specified as propositions. A geometric proposition is a true proposition about the implication of a geometric relationship (referred to as the conclusion of the theorem) in all diagrams that fulfill the same set of geometric relationships (referred to as the hypothesis of the theorem). Surprisingly, geometric theorems can be generated automatically and effectively from the information obtained from diagram images in three steps: generating candidate sets, excluding false candidates and proving the theorems obtained.

sections.heading: 3.1 Generating Candidates
sections.text: It can be easily generated by selecting one (or more) geometric relation (s) as a conclusion and assuming some relationships other than the hypothesis. Since there are geometric objects and relationships that are irrelevant to the properties of the diagram, it is necessary to remove such objects and relationships for the efficiency of the theorem. It is necessary to determine such objects and relationships for the intersection of two lines or an intersection of two circles and a circle. A point of interest is referred to as a point of attraction if it is an end point of a segment, or the starting point of a half line or the intersection of two lines, or an intersection of two circles and a circle. Or the tangent point of two circles or a circle, or an isolated point. Points of attraction play an important role in the formation of the diagram problem. A point of attraction is referred to as a characteristic point when used in the expressions of properties or specifications of the J positions.

sections.heading: 3.2 Ruling out False Candidates
sections.text: To verify the truth of a candidate position, we use algebraic methods that have been successfully applied to automated geometric theorems. (For the efficiency of theorem mining, false proposals must first be excluded, so that any proposal submitted to a theorem tester must be a potential theorem. (A counter-example of a proposal is a diagram that is subject to the hypothesis of the proposal, but not the conclusion of the proposal.) If a counter-example can be found, then the proposal does not have to be a theorem. In what follows, we present a numerical verification technique based on the characteristic method of Wu [24, 22] to find counter-examples to exclude false propositions.

sections.heading: 3.3 Proving Theorems

sections.heading: 4 Implementation and Experiments
sections.text: "The effectiveness of the approach we have proposed for generating geometric theories depends on the perfection and accuracy of the information we have retrieved and on the efficiency of the theorem we have applied." In this section, we will have to deal with the question of how to spread geometric theorems. "The algorithms described in Section 2 are able to test the diagrams and determine the characteristics of people who are able to establish a dynamic geometry system for the interactive construction of diagrams," says the author.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Geometric Information Retrieval
sections.text: In addition to the Hough transformation, random algorithms for detecting lines and circles have been proposed in [4, 5]. These algorithms save a certain amount of memory space by first randomly computing a candidate line or circle, and then performing a proof-gathering process to further determine whether the line or circle actually exists. Note that most shape-detection methods are used to extract rough shapes of object edges from general images, and their accuracy need not be very high. To detect geometric objects, it is crucial to use OpenCV with numerical data (such as coordinates of points) to ensure that the accuracy of detection results is high enough for geometric relationships implied in diagram images to be correctly determined by numerical calculations.

sections.heading: 5.2 Geometric Theorem Discovery
sections.text: The reader can use [6, 8, 9, 17, 20, 21, 24] and the references contained therein for extensive studies of algebraic methods (based on character sets, triangular decomposition, and GrÃ ¶ bner fundamentals) for automatic testing and discovery of geometric theorems. As examples, we cite the open web-based tool [3] developed for the automatic discovery of theorems and relationships in elementary Euclidean geometry, and the deductive database approach [7] proposed for the search for all properties implicit in given geometric configurations. Compared to the existing work, the ability to discover non-trivial theorems or deductive relationships to geometric relationships that arise automatically from given images of diagrams reflects the novelty of our approach.

sections.heading: 5.3 Other Related Work
sections.text: In addition to coordinate-based algebraic methods, other methods of automated theory testing can be included in our approach to verifying the accuracy of candidate proposals, such as the area method, the full angle method, the bracket algebra method, methods based on Clifford algebra, axiom-based deductive methods and diagrammatic argumentation methods (see [2, 6, 21] and references to them) Some dynamic geometry software systems have implemented special methods (e.g. randomized testing methods in Cinderella [14]) to prove theorems for constructed diagrams or interfaces to geometric theory proofs for generating evidence in diagrams [23, 26] and knowledge in repositories of geometric constructions and proofs [19]. A web-based library of problems in geometry is created for testing and evaluating proofs and tools of automated theorems.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: The approach proposed in this paper opens up a completely new avenue for the discovery and reasoning of geometric knowledge: the retrieval of characteristic information (geometric objects and their relationships) from simple and inaccurate data (diagram images), the generation of potential knowledge (candidate proposals) from the information retrieved, and the discovery of profound knowledge (geometric theorems) and their validation by automated reasoning (evidence of geometric theorems).The success of our approach demonstrates the feasibility of automatically acquiring formalized geometric knowledge in quantity from a large scale of diagram images available in electronic documents and resources, and the efficient management of this knowledge in a retrievable structure with diagrams instead of ambiguous statements in natural languages. Our work is still ongoing. Further experiments are being conducted, and further techniques and strategies are being developed to recover the accuracy of retrieving geometric information from images and to derive static relationships from it to suitable candidates, in order to improve the efficiency of the specifications.
